docs.snippet: President Josip Broz Tito is 79 and an increasingly pertinent question in European politics has been: Who will succeed him as Yugoslavia's leader? Marshal Tito himself raised the issue last September, and yesterday there were further revelations...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Josip Broz Tito is 79 and an increasingly pertinent question in European politics has been: Who will succeed him as Yugoslavia's leader? Marshal Tito himself raised the issue last September, and yesterday there were further revelations about what he had in mind.

docs.snippet: A new judging system, similar to the ones used in figure skating and diving, is being tried in the horse shows on the Florida Sunshine Circuit.
docs.lead_paragraph: A new judging system, similar to the ones used in figure skating and diving, is being tried in the horse shows on the Florida Sunshine Circuit.

headline.main: Judges Try New Scoring System Of Flashing Cards in Florida

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Wednesday, March 3 -- Dr. Claude L. Fly, a United States agronomist who was kidnapped nearly seven months ago by leftist urban guerrillas, was set free last night. Suffering from a heart attack, he was left in a stretcher at the...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Wednesday, March 3 -- Dr. Claude L. Fly, a United States agronomist who was kidnapped nearly seven months ago by leftist urban guerrillas, was set free last night. Suffering from a heart attack, he was left in a stretcher at the gates of a hospital.
docs.abstract: Dr C L Fly left by Tupamaros in stretcher at gates of Brit Hosp near downtown Montevideo after being held for nearly 7 mos; is suffering from heart attack; talks to US Amb Adair, says he is anxious to see family again; illus; condition reptd serious; police set up roadblocks but are unable to apprehend kidnappers

headline.main: Uruguayan Leftists Free U.S. Adviser Seized in '70; Uruguayan Leftists Free U.S. Farm Adviser Kidnapped in 1970

docs.snippet: Mrs J M Fly, daughter-in-law, says family 1st learned about release when US radio station called; says Fly's wife has spoken by telephone with Sec Rogers; family to hold news conf at home, Fort Collins, Colo
docs.abstract: Mrs J M Fly, daughter-in-law, says family 1st learned about release when US radio station called; says Fly's wife has spoken by telephone with Sec Rogers; family to hold news conf at home, Fort Collins, Colo

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 3 (AP) -- Dr. Fly was reported in "delicate condition and resting" today at British Hospital.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 3 (AP) -- Dr. Fly was reported in "delicate condition and resting" today at British Hospital.
docs.abstract: Fly reptd in 'delicate condition'; Adair says he probably will remain in hosp 3-4 wks; Tupamaro statement says Fly was informed Feb 18 of planned release, that he suffered heart attack Feb 23; contends that Fly was freed under amnesty but diplomatic sources believe Tupamaros panicked when he was taken ill

docs.snippet: FORT COLLINS, Colo., March 3 -- The wife and son of them American agricultural adviser who was held for seven months as a hostage in Uruguay accused the State Department and the Uruguayan Government today of lack of action and refusals to negotiate...
docs.lead_paragraph: FORT COLLINS, Colo., March 3 -- The wife and son of them American agricultural adviser who was held for seven months as a hostage in Uruguay accused the State Department and the Uruguayan Government today of lack of action and refusals to negotiate with the Tupamaro guerrillas.
docs.abstract: Fly's wife, son score US and Uruguayan Govts for refusing to negotiate with Tupamaros, charging inaction was responsible for near death of Fly, news conf, Colo home; wife earlier received Pres Nixon note pledging further effort in rescuing Fly; says she expected 'a lot more' from US Govt

headline.main: U.S. AND URUGUAY SCORED ON DR. FLY; Freed American's Wife and Son Charge Inaction

byline.original: By ANTHONY RIPLEYSpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: " I'm happy and excited about finding myself among free men again," said Claude L. Fly on his release after being held hostage for seven months by Uruguay's Tupamaro terrorists. Americans and Uruguayans will share that happiness with Dr. Fly and his...
docs.lead_paragraph: " I'm happy and excited about finding myself among free men again," said Claude L. Fly on his release after being held hostage for seven months by Uruguay's Tupamaro terrorists. Americans and Uruguayans will share that happiness with Dr. Fly and his family, along with the hope for his rapid recovery from the heart attack that obviously led to his release.
docs.abstract: ed on Fly's release backs Uruguayan Govt's decision not to negotiate with Tupamaros

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 2 -- By scaring off masses of Argentine tourists with threats of violence, Uruguay's Tupamaro guerrillas have severely damaged their nation's economy -- an achievement that is among their announced objectives.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 2 -- By scaring off masses of Argentine tourists with threats of violence, Uruguay's Tupamaro guerrillas have severely damaged their nation's economy -- an achievement that is among their announced objectives.
docs.abstract: Tupamaros severely hurting econ, heavily dependent on tourism, by scaring off Argentine tourists with threats of violence, thus achieving 1 of announced guerrilla objectives

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNESpecial to The New York Times
